Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

---

In my opinion, this argument is a sound base, but is only half of the picture. I think college athletes should be paid - they are essentially working for their schools, and should be compensated as other student workers are. 

That said, the argument that paying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni is a valid one. Or rather, that it could hurt students, schools, etc. It doesn't have to. It would be complicated, but rules, limits, and regulations could be developed to prevent or solve most of the issues that would arise from paying student athletes.

It could be argued that it is inherently unfair - that some sports are more popular than others, and that some schools have more money than others. Which is true. But some schools already have more money than others, better teams than others, and have other advantages. And the same with students - some are just better athletes and are highly courted already.

It seems unfair to take advantage of students talents and not compensate them. Yes, certain athletes in popular sports will make more money, and certain schools will be more desirable than others. But tht is post-school life anyway - graduates with degrees from "better"  schools have an easier time finding better, higher paying jobs, and student athletes from schools with strong programs are more likely to go on to be professional athletes.
